Word Ruling
Maryland's highest court
ruled Wednesday that the
word "fuck" is neither legally obscene nor profane. The
case involved a man who
allegedly shouted the word
at a police officer. The court
ruled that use of the term is
not grounds for a disorderly
conduct charge. They said
the word is not profane
because it does not refer to
something divine or holy. To
be ruled obscene it would
have to be erotic, and since
the term does not "denote a
tendency to excite sexual
desire," it does not fit this
description either.

prerogative to amend the SAC
constitution.

noting that it would not allow
the council to change the SAC
constitution, even if it were instructed to do so by a student
referendum. The amendment
was rewritten to allow for such
a contingency and passed by the
Executive Board on Monday.

the Student Council meeting

tied at six in favor, six against
and six abstaining. Student
Council . president Doug
Fellman voted to break the tie,
giving the amendment its 7-6-6
margin of victory.

Student Council Re-evaluates
Merits of Membership In AAUS
BY BRUCE ALPERT
l'he Student Council held a
lengthy debate last Wednesday
night about whether it should
renew its membership in the
American Association of
University Students. The
AAUS is an organization which
meets periodically to discuss the
strengths and weaknesses of
student-geared activities at
more than 50 research universities throughout the nation.
Council has tabled further
discussion of the AAUS until
next week's meeting at which
time it will hear .a full report on
the costs and advantages of
joining this organization from
last year's delegation.

Hopkins joined the AAUS
last year on a trial basis. The
Student Council appropriated
approximately $1000 to send a
delegation to the organization's
national conference held last
year at the University of Pennsylvania. According to Robert
Finkel, a member of that
delegation, each participant at
the convention was assigned to
groups that looked into problems encountered by, as well
as the strengths of, variou.s
schools. Students would compare ideas as to how these problems were dealt with at the
Schools in an effort to improve
their treatment of such
weaknesses.
Gary Millev, another of last
year's delegates, said the AAUS

"has great poter11a think
tank. If every university implemented these suggestions, it
would make schools that much
better for the students."
However, Colin Flynn, who
has been studying the AAUS's
constitution, warned that the
Association is "a tight, topheavy organization" which
operates all year round with little input from its member
universities. Noted Flynn,
delegates meet at a regional
conference and at a national
conference in the fall and spring
respectively, but "the rest of
the year [the organization's] officers are publishing whatever
they want without our approval. We may not even hear
what they do."

pedestrian accidents around campus, two of
them on Charles Street. The most serious of
